awd_titl_txt: EAGER Germination: What we talk about when we talk about big ideas: Using case studies to train PhD students in ideation and questioning processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project from the University of Iowa seeks to develop courses for training graduate students in scientific ideation and questioning to address societal challenges, using case studies of scientists who achieved major breakthroughs. The project builds on successful pilot studies of teaching ideation and questioning, and seeks ultimately to develop formalized teaching modules that could be disseminated for use beyond the University of Iowa. This study has two potential Broader Impacts. Firstly, the training programs under development may inculcate in all participants a deepened ability to relate scientific research to societal needs. Secondly, the training programs may make scientific idea-framing and questioning processes more visible and accessible to underrepresented groups, including first-generation students, facilitating their engagement with STEM careers, and thereby diversifying and strengthening the scientific workforce.

This project will use case studies of celebrated, high-achieving scientists for training graduate students in ambitious scientific ideation and questioning tethered to societal needs. Two different approaches will be compared in parallel to identify their affordances and limitations. The first is a semester-length course that will step chemistry and engineering graduate students through processes of ideation and question development using a well scaffolded 16-week framework. The second approach involves an informal drop-in weekly seminar/workshop (Reading-Writing Workshop; RWW) that will run for a year. Both courses will share some elements, including employing case studies to enable the students to tease out the processes of ideation and questioning, leveraging social scientists to provide larger perspectives on societal needs, and introducing a conceptual framework that connects critical societal needs to the guiding questions of physical science research communities. Case study work will include reviewing papers, memoirs, letter, and oral histories of significant scientists to explore their processes of idea generation, questioning of key assumptions, and integration of disciplinary approaches. The underlying hypothesis is that through considering ways in which important scientific ideas and questions are generated graduate students will develop both increased desire and increased ability to formulate and engage with important questions. Outcome evaluation will include Likert-based and qualitative assessments based on existing instruments for measuring student learning. The PIs expect that this research will lead to the development of flexible-use, "inoculatory" teaching modules for seeding a vigorously inquisitive, opportunity-seeking, broad-minded culture in groups or departments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project at the University of Iowa tested two methods of training graduate students to generate scientific questions and ideas independently. Such independence can be unfamiliar to STEM students, who are often accustomed to working on professors' projects rather than developing their own. Furthermore, we wanted to train students to consider what their science had to do with major societal needs, such as clean water and the care of aging populations: this is also difficult for students whose courses seldom deal with social issues. Finally, since science and engineering driven by societal needs is frequently interdisciplinary, we wanted to train students to work interdisciplinarily.

Our first method adapted a reading and writing group (RWG) structure we had used for training members of individual research groups to think deeply and independently about their projects and to write publishable papers. These freewheeling, informal groups had greatly improved students' ability to generate and communicate powerful ideas and questions, but it was a slow process serving a few committed students at a time. Our test RWG met weekly for a year, during which time we worked on students' papers, applications, and other projects as they arose. We connected their research to societal needs frequently and intentionally, through visitor talks, readings, and discussion, but otherwise did not interfere with the RWG process.

The second method, Questioning and Ideation (QI), took a less organic approach and did not involve students' real research. This semester-length formal program scaffolded the interdisciplinary, collaborative generation of societal-need-driven research project ideas. We recruited twelve graduate students from chemistry, engineering, and chemistry education, and met twice weekly, with students forming interdisciplinary, societal-interest-based groups of three.

Both QI and RWG began with presentations from social scientists introducing students to their areas of research.

We found that the interventions did not affect the RWG's scientific output. Students found the societal questions interesting, and at one point stayed late to discuss why they should talk with social scientists at all, systematically exploring what researchers and practicioners across disciplines do, how they define and acquire knowledge, and what types of questions they ask. Students concluded that all physical-science research should involve a social scientist to guide its utility, and left wondering whether they could justify research that did not deal obviously with societal needs. However, they (accurately) did not perceive these societal questions as important to their progress to graduation or scientific publication, and their discussion of societal needs was not evident in their scientific thinking and writing.

The QI group, though, were freed during our meetings from publication and graduation concerns. They addressed themselves to societal problems raised by the social scientists; formed societal-interest-based working groups; engaged in research into their societal issues; then became dedicated to solving distinct societal problems that they cared about and believed could be solved technologically. They worked together to develop scientific questions and ideas: each group tried to use the backgrounds and skills of all team members, which required them to understand each others' disciplines and points of view, and translate their ideas across disciplinary borders. They found no research literatures that both spanned their fields and dealt with the societal problems they cared about, and found they had to act as pioneers, relying on their own judgment, but also finding relevant expert advisors to consult. As each group refined its project to focus on a narrow, practicable goal, they learned to write brief project proposals for communication to both expert and broad audiences. All groups succeeded in developing projects, most of which were found plausible by both the social scientists and a group of the students' advisors. Students reported advances in questioning and ideation, connecting science to social needs, and working interdisciplinarily. Overall, their confidence and intellectual independence also increased. (See figure.) However, we also found that most QI students were driven so strongly to solve societal problems with existing knowledge that we could not interest them in looking for questions of greater intellectual merit.

We see that graduate science and engineering students, given permission and scaffolding, engage societal problems avidly. Finding overlap between intellectual merit and societal service, however, remains difficult. Instruction that overtly explores the tensions, overlap, and feedbacks between basic and applied research could be helpful, and lead graduate students to begin living with this consideration of how they might advance our knowledge of nature while keeping one eye on major societal needs.
